introduction.p: Matrix transformations, which we explored in the last section, allow us to describe certain functions T:\real^n\to\real^m. In this section, we will demonstrate how matrix transformations provide a convenient way to describe geometric operations, such as rotations, reflections, and scalings. We will then explore how matrix transformations are used in computer animation.

subsection.p: The previous activity presented some examples showing that matrix transformations can perform interesting geometric operations, such as rotations, scalings, and reflections. Before we go any further, we should explain why it is possible to represent these operations by matrix transformations. In fact, we ask more generally: what types of functions T:\real^n\to\real^m are represented as matrix transformations?
The result is the following proposition.

statement.p:
The function T:\real^n\to\real^m is a matrix transformation where T(\xvec) = A\xvec for some m\times n matrix A if and only if
\begin{aligned} T(c\vvec) \amp {}={} cT(\vvec) \\ T(\vvec + \wvec) \amp {}={} T(\vvec) + T(\wvec)\text{.} \end{aligned} . In this case, A is the matrix whose columns are T(\evec_j); that is,
A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} T(\evec_1) \amp T(\evec_2) \amp \ldots \amp T(\evec_n) \end{array}\right] .

subsection.p: Said simply, this proposition means says that if have a function T:\real^n\to\real^m and can verify the two linearity properties stated in the proposition, then we know that T is a matrix transformation. Let's see how this works in practice.

statement.p: We will consider the function T:\real^2\to\real^2 that rotates a vector \xvec by 45^\circ in the counterclockwise direction to obtain T(\xvec) as seen in .

figure.caption: The function T rotates a vector counterclockwise by 45^\circ.

statement.p: The next two figures illustrate why these properties hold. For instance, shows the relationship between T(\vvec) and T(c\vvec) when c is a scalar. In particular, scaling a vector and then rotating it is the same as rotating and then scaling it, which means that T(c\vvec) = cT(\vvec).

figure.caption: We see that the vector T(c\vvec) is a scalar multiple to T(\vvec) so that T(c\vvec) = cT(\vvec).

statement.p: Similarly, shows the relationship between T(\vvec+\wvec), T(\vvec), and T(\wvec). Remember that the sum of two vectors is represented by the diagonal of the parallelogram defined by the two vectors. The rotation T has the effect of rotating the parallelogram defined by \vvec and \wvec into the parallelogram defined by T(\vvec) and T(\wvec), explaining why T(\vvec+\wvec) = T(\vvec) + T(\wvec).

figure.caption: We see that the vector T(\vvec+\wvec) is the sum of T(\vvec) and T(\wvec) so that T(\vvec + \wvec) = T(\vvec) + T(\wvec).

statement.p: Having verified these two properties, we now know that the function T that rotates vectors by 45^\circ is a matrix transformation. We may therefore write it as T(\xvec) = A\xvec where A is the 2\times2 matrix A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} T(\evec_1) \amp T(\evec_2) \end{array}\right]. The columns of this matrix, T(\evec_1) and T(\evec_2), are shown on the right of .

figure.caption: The matrix transformation T rotates \evec_1 and \evec_2 by 45^\circ.

statement.p: Notice that T(\evec_1) forms an isosceles right triangle, as shown in . Since the length of \evec_1 is 1, the length of T(\evec_1), the hypotenuse of the triangle, is also 1, and by Pythagoras' theorem, the lengths of its legs are 1/\sqrt{2}.

figure.caption: The vector T(\evec_1) has length 1 and is the hypotenuse of a right isosceles triangle.

statement.p:
This leads to T(\evec_1) = \twovec{\frac1{\sqrt{2}}} {\frac1{\sqrt{2}}}. In the same way, we find that T(\evec_2) = \twovec{-\frac1{\sqrt{2}}} {\frac1{\sqrt{2}}} so that the matrix A is
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \amp -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \amp \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\ \end{array}\right] . You may wish to check this using the interactive diagram in the previous activity using the approximation 1/\sqrt{2} \approx 0.7.

subsection.p:
In this example, we found that T, a function describing a rotation in the plane, was in fact a matrix transformation by checking that
\begin{aligned} T(c\vvec) \amp {}={} cT(\vvec) \\ T(\vvec + \wvec) \amp {}={} T(\vvec) + T(\wvec)\text{.} \end{aligned}.
The same kind of thinking applies more generally to show that rotations, reflections, and scalings are matrix transformations. Similarly, we could revisit the functions in and verify that they are matrix transformations.

subsection.title: Matrix transformations and computer animation
subsection.p: Linear algebra plays a significant role in computer animation. We will now illustrate how matrix transformations and some of the ideas we have developed in this section are used by computer animators to create the illusion of motion in their characters.

shows a test character used by Pixar animators. On the left is the original definition of the character; on the right, we see that the character has been moved into a different pose. To make it appear that the character is moving, animators create a sequence of frames in which the character's pose is modified slightly from one frame to the next often using matrix transformations.

figure.caption: Computer animators define a character and create motion by drawing it in a sequence of poses. Disney/Pixar

sidebyside.p: Of course, realistic characters will be drawn in three-dimensions. To keep things a little more simple, however, we will look at this two-dimensional character and devise matrix transformations that move them into different poses.

subsection.p: Of course, the first thing we may wish to do is simply move them to a different position in the plane, such as that shown in . Motions like this are called translations.

figure.caption: Translating our character to a new position in the plane.

subsection.p: This presents a problem because a matrix transformation T:\real^2\to\real^2 has the property that T(\zerovec) = A\zerovec = \zerovec. This means that a matrix transformation cannot move the origin of the coordinate plane. To address this restriction, animators use homogeneous coordinates, which are formed by placing the two-dimensional coordinate plane inside \real^3 as the plane z=1, as shown in .

figure.caption: Include the two-dimensional coordinate plane in \real^3 as the plane z=1 so that we can translate the character.

subsection.p: As a result, rather than describing points in the plane as vectors \twovec{x}{y}, we describe them as three-dimensional vectors \threevec{x}{y}{1}. As we see in the next activity, this allows us to translate our character in the plane.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
This section explored how geometric operations are performed by matrix transformations.
A function T:\real^n\to\real^m is a matrix transformation if and only if these properties are satisfied:
\begin{aligned} T(c\vvec) \amp = cT(\vvec) \\ T(\vvec+\wvec) \amp = T(\vvec)+T(\wvec). \\ \end{aligned}
Geometric operations, such as rotations, reflections, and scalings, can be represented as matrix transformations.
Composing geometric operations corresponds to matrix multiplication.
Computer animators use homogeneous coordinates and matrix transformations to create the illusion of motion.
